description: From Middle English tit, titte, tette, from Old English tit, titt, from Proto-West Germanic *titt, from Proto-Germanic *tittaz (“teat; nipple; breast”), of expressive origin.
Perhaps related to an original meaning “to suck”; compare Proto-Indo-European *dʰeh₁-y-. Doublet of teat, which was borrowed from Old French.

entries.meaning: (now often considered vulgar) A mammary gland, teat.
(slang, vulgar, chiefly in the plural) A person's breast or nipple.
(Britain, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, derogatory, slang) An idiot; a fool.
examples: Look at that tit driving on the wrong side of the road!

entries.meaning: (UK, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, slang, derogatory) A police officer; a "tithead".

description: Perhaps imitative of light tap. Compare earlier tip for tap (“blow for blow”), from tip + tap; compare also dialectal tint for tant.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A light blow or hit (now usually in the phrase tit for tat).

verbs.description: tit (third-person singular simple present tits, present participle titting, simple past and past participle titted)

entries.meaning: (transitive or intransitive, obsolete) To strike lightly, tap, pat.

description: Probably of North Germanic/Scandinavian origin; found earliest in titling and titmouse; compare Faroese títlingur, dialectal Norwegian titling (“small stockfish”).

entries.meaning: A chickadee; a small passerine bird of the genus Parus or the family Paridae, common in the Northern Hemisphere.
Any of various other small passerine birds.
(archaic) A young girl, later especially a minx, hussy.

examples: Being drunk , he remembers not a tit of life before the drink came well home. It is not that he sees the past mistily; he does not see at all. He lives then only in as much of the present as the word of his master for the time being […]
